titlestmt.titleproper: Ford Foundation records, Knowledge, Creativity, and Freedom Program (KCF), Media, Arts, and Culture unit (MAC) Office Files of Margaret Wilkerson
Ford Foundation records, Knowledge, Creativity, and Freedom Program (KCF), Media, Arts, and Culture unit (MAC) Office Files of Margaret Wilkerson FA1832
titlestmt.author: Ford Foundation records, Knowledge, Creativity, and Freedom Program (KCF), Media, Arts, and Culture unit (MAC) Office Files of Margaret Wilkerson

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2024-10-01 04:57:52 UTC.
profiledesc.langusage: Description is written in: English, Latin script.

did.unittitle: Ford Foundation records, Knowledge, Creativity, and Freedom Program (KCF), Media, Arts, and Culture unit (MAC) Office Files of Margaret Wilkerson

physdesc.extent: 16 document containers: 14 letter boxes, 1 legal box, and 1 oversize box

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Ford Foundation has title, copyright and literary rights in the collection, in so far as it holds them.

The Rockefeller Archive Center has authority to grant permission to cite and publish material from the collection. Permission to publish extensive excerpts, or material in its entirety, will be referred to the Ford Foundation.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Ford Foundation archive was deposited at the RAC in 2011. Ford Foundation records, correspondence, reports, program files, and officers' papers were transferred to and accessioned by the RAC beginning in 2011.
This material was transferred to the RAC in 2020 and 2021 in three different sets of records and was ingested by the RAC as Accessions 2020:021, Accession 2020:023, and Accession 2021:004.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Open for research with select materials restricted as noted. Brittle or damaged items are available at the discretion of RAC. Researchers interested in accessing digital media (floppy disks, CDs, DVDs, etc.) in this collection must use an access surrogate. The original items may not be accessed because of preservation concerns. To request an access surrogate be made, or if you are unsure if there is an access surrogate, please contact an archivist.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Collection contains the office files Margaret Wilkerson created when she worked at the Ford Foundation, overseeing grant programming for arts, education, culture, and media. Materials in the collection carry though from when Wilkerson joined the Foundation as a Program Officer in the Education, Media, Arts, and Culture Program (EMAC), Media, Arts, and Culture unit (MAC), to her becoming Director of MAC, to the reorganization of the Foundation's arts and culture programming and installation of MAC in the Knowledge, Creativity, and Freedom Program (KCF) between 1998 and 2007. They primarily document Wilkerson's review and support of grantee organizations and her participation and leadership in MAC's and the larger Foundation's program strategy and initiatives.
Common materials formats found within the collection include correspondence, meeting notes, drafts, reports, meeting materials, and CDs.

did.unittitle: Subject files

physdesc.extent: 16 document containers: 14 letter boxes, 1 legal box, and 1 oversize box

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series consists of subject files created by Margaret Wilkerson during the time she worked at the Ford Foundation between 1998 and 2007. The files document her activities through her tenures as Program Officer in the Education, Media, Arts, and Culture Program (EMAC), Media, Arts and Culture unit (MAC), Director of MAC, and Director of MAC within the reorganized Knowledge, Creativity, and Freedom Program (KCF).

Wilkerson's responsibilities for reviewing and supporting grants related to art, education, culture, and media are documented in proposals, evaluations, correspondence, reports, brochures and other promotional materials. Much of Wilkerson's correspondence is between her and grantee organizations and between her and other Ford Foundation staff members in the Foundation's education and culture program areas. Wilkerson was supported in her work by her assistant Audrey Simon.

A significant number of files in the series pertain to Wilkerson's attendance and support of different convenings and trips. These files contain materials such as agendas, drafts, and notes. The convenings and trips were related to grantee organizations as well as the Foundation's internal meetings for program strategy. One of the Foundation's internal initiatives that many of Wilkerson's files concern centered around affirmative action. There are several publications in the series about affirmative action research.
